text: CAMERA PANS a group of freshly-scrubbed, innocent childre obediently standing in line, like recruits for the Holy  Crusade. PULL BACK to REVEAL they are wearing the gray  blazers, striped ties and navy slacks of St. Luke's Schoo They are waiting patiently at the curbside in front of th statue of the school's sainted namesake. One of the fifth grade BOYS pokes the KID next to him with his elbow. The  other Kid is about to retaliate when SISTER MARY FRANCIS, stern-faced nun, appears behind them, grabbing them both  firmly by the shoulders.
Make one more move and you'll both  be staying late for the rest of the  week.
(softly; in unison) Sorry, Sister Mary Francis.
I didn't hear you.
(louder) Sorry, Sister Mary Francis.

Sister Mary Francis checks her watch. She scowls and look out past the parking lot gate. Suddenly we HEAR the SOUND of an ENGINE roaring at full  throttle. There is a SCREECHING of BRAKES, followed by th loud GRINDING of GEARS. It sounds like the Indy 500 is ta place around the corner.
(used to this) Step away from the curb, children.

Zooming through the parking lot gates is a large yellow s bus. It practically takes the last turn on just two wheel The bus driver quickly slams on the brakes, leaving ten f of rubber behind him as the bus comes to an ear-splitting halt right in front of them. The front door immediately s open and RICK STAHL, the driver, hops out. Rick is the li of the party, even when there isn't any party going on. While chronologically older than the St. Luke students, t only thing that sets him apart from them is that he has a driver's license. Rick figures he'll live up to his  capabilities and get serious in his next life... This  incarnation's strictly for laughs. Sister Mary Francis st up to him.
You're late again, Rick.
I know, Sister, but I have a very  good excuse.
There can be no excuse for tardiness.
You're absolutely right. I should  never have stopped to save that  drowning infant. I'm just weak,  Sister; I'm so weak.
He starts sobbing softly into his hands.
All right, stop that... Children, on  the bus.
The kids obediently file past Rick, who makes like he is  drying his tears with his handkerchief.
Sister, do you ever get lonely after  vespers? If you do, why don't you  give me a call. I'm in the book.
(smiling despite  herself) Get going, Rick... you're late enough  as it is.
Right... Think it over.
He hops on the bus, closes the door and gently backs the out of the parking lot.

As soon as the bus is out of sight of the school, all hel breaks loose. The formally well-mannered children are act like normal kids... hitting each other over the heads wit books, running up and down the aisles, screaming at the t of their lungs.

He removes the St. Christopher statue from the dashboard, revealing a hulaing Hawaiian girl in a grass skirt. He wa the madness behind him in his rearview mirror, picks up t P.A. microphone and rationally attempts to restore order.
(over mike) If you don't all calm down I'm gonna  drive this thing over a cliff.
The kids pay no attention to him.
(continuing;  philosophically) Ah... youth.

Rick's bus pulls up to a light and another school bus fil with kids (from a public school) pulls up alongside of it The other DRIVER gives Rick a competitive smirk and guns engine. Rick counters by gunning his.
All the kids start screaming "Race... race." "Wipe 'em ou "Go for it." Etc. Some of the kids even start taking out  money and start betting one another on the race's outcome
as he readies for action.
The light turns green and they're off. Or as off as two l school buses filled with kids can be.
The two buses come zooming down the street.
The kids are screaming at Rick to go faster. One of the l boys looks nauseous as he clutches the seat in front of h
The buses squeeze down a narrow street, neck and neck wit one another.

The kids are all yelling words of encouragement to Rick, is hunched over in his seat, driving with the determinati of Andy Granitelli. The nauseous kid is now turning a pal shade of green. He moves to an open window, straining to  control the inevitable.
They race down a steep hill.
The nauseous kid can't hold it any longer.
Something hits with a splat against the windshield that  resembles Campbell's Chunky Vegetable Soup.
The other Driver turns on the windshield. It only makes i worse.
Rick's bus pulls out in front, accompanied by the cheerin of his passengers. Suddenly a stop light looms ahead. Ric puts on his brakes. Both buses stop just in time.
Rick's kids are all piled in a clump right behind him in front of the bus. Although disheveled, the kids still man a victorious cheer.
We're LOOKING THROUGH the camera lens. We SEE a cute one- year-old baby boy. He's sitting on a cuddly blanket. We H the VOICE of Jay O'Neill. He is a baby photographer at Se
Okay, Timmy... hold that smile...  and watch the birdie.
He takes the picture and we SEE the camera flash.
There.

We see he has his camera and backdrop set up in the camer department behind a velour curtain which blacks out the r of the store. He's conservatively dressed in a suit, vest and tie. He looks like he could be a Young Republican. Bu under those Sears clothes is a man a little off center. R best friend. Need we say more? He takes the film out of t camera. The matronly mother is in the process of gatherin up her baby.
These should be in the mail to you  by next Friday.
She smiles and exits.
(continuing) Next.

A beautiful -- and we're talking gorgeous -- WOMAN enters Her clothes hug every curve of her body. She has her baby her arms. O'Neill immediately wants her, and now. His eye settle onto her full breasts. These he likes.
(continuing) Whoa. Look at those babies.
She gets this innuendo and loves it.
(continuing) How are we doing? My name is O'Neill.  And you are...?
Klupner. (teasing) Mrs. Klupner.
Mrs.?
I'm separated.
Then there is a God. Why don't we  take that baby picture.
He takes the baby. He has a hard time taking his eyes off her breasts. He places the baby on the blanket.
(continuing) If I were you, I'd breast feed until  I was 17 or 18. (gets behind camera;  sizing up the shot) Tell ya what...
We SEE the baby sitting on the blanket.
Why don't you lean into the picture  with your child?
She coyly leans INTO FRAME.
(continuing) A-huh. A little more... good!
She is totally blocking her baby out of the picture.
He gets out from behind the camera.
I'm getting one heck of a glare off  your dress there. Could you undo a  few buttons?
(seductively) Of course.
She starts to unbutton her blouse. O'Neill looks into his camera.
We SEE the Woman finish her last button.
Now lean in a little more... more...  more...
As she complies, her breasts all but spill out of her dre
(continuing) Hold that pose.
He runs from behind the camera and poses with the woman.
We SEE a QUICK SERIES of camera flashes. Each pose finds near her breasts. He has them on his head. He's cheek to  breast. Etc.
enters and witnesses the photo session. He immediately ju into the shots.
Rick joins the craziness. After several beats, the Woman  gets bored and EXITS the FRAME.
As Rick and O'Neill continue mugging like two 12-year-old in a photo booth, the Woman takes her child and exits. A beats pass and the guys notice they're alone.
Where'd she go?
She probably had sex scheduled for  12:30. O'Neill, let's pick up the  guys for a drink... I have major  news to announce.
O'Neill crosses to his camera and takes out the film.
Okay... be right with ya.
He picks up some photographs of today's work.
Each one has a different mother in several seductive pose Their babies are barely visible, if at all.
Pictures a family will cherish  forever.
Rick's school bus pulls into the yard of the auto shop.  Several Chicanos are working on various cars. Rick and O' hop out.
Hey, Chulo, where are you, man?
We SEE a very large pair of shoes sticking out from under the chassis. Slowly, a large, bear-like body rolls out an we catch our first glimpse of CHULO. A happy-go-lucky mec of Mexican ancestry.
Hey, you guys, what's going on?
We're going for a little liquid  refreshment.
Great. I'll go with you. Wait a  second. Hey, Raul! Move that car,  will you?
A SMALL MECHANIC with an eye patch gets into a car behind them as we DOLLY WITH the guys THROUGH the lot.
(continuing) Roberto, you finished fixing that  lighter yet?
Another MECHANIC sticks his face out of another car and s his head. Just then Raul, the eye-patched worker, whizzes behind the guys, driving the car in a zig-zag pattern rig into traffic.
(continuing; to Rick) I'm glad you guys came by... What's  the occasion?
Rick's got an important announcement  to make.
Yeah. What is it?
I've decided not to run for President.
Too bad, man, that blows my chance  to be Ambassador to France.
Behind them we can SEE Roberto fiddling with the lighter. Suddenly flames leap out of the car, blowing Roberto ten  feet into the air.
The guys all start to pile into the bus. Nearby another  employee is washing down the garage with a hose. Chulo turns to another mechanic, who has his head under t hood of a car.
Manuel, be sure and finish up the  electrical system on that Chevy.

Manuel waves at Chulo, who turns, hops on the bus. Rick s it up and starts to drive away. Just as the bus CLEARS FR we SEE Manuel connect two wires together at the same mome the guy with the hose washes down the area around his fee Manuel lights up like a Christmas tree, screaming in pain There is a beat, and then Robert falls INTO FRAME, still  holding the cigarette lighter, and the car Raul is drivin enters the lot and smashes into the side of the garage.

A sign on an office door says "CONCERT TICKET AGENCY." Fr inside we HEAR someone TALKING loudly on the phone. Chulo Rick and O'Neill open the door and go inside. On the wall in the cramped office there are rock 'n' roll concert pos advertising rock bands like Men At Work, The Clash and Ba Manilow. Behind a cluttered desk we FIND a little man wit thin mustache and horn-rimmed glasses. This is GARY MELNI wheeler-dealer, entrepreneur and coward. Gary yells a lot which is a definite overcompensation for his size and  inability to deal with the opposite sex.

(yelling; into phone) Screw you... Screw that... Don't  jerk me around. You promised me 1500  seats for the Police Concert... 1500,  not fifteen!... Screw that... Screw  you -- Screw Sting. (hangs up and sees  the guys standing  there) Hi, guys.
Gary, you're quite an animal.
Screw you...
The PHONE RINGS.
(continuing; into  phone) Hello, Concert tickets... What? Pat  Benitar has a yeast infection? She's  cancelling? Screw her. You know what  this is gonna cost me?... (he hangs up) Okay. Let's go.
He gets up and they start for the door. Just then the PHO RINGS. Gary picks it up.
(annoyed) Screw you... That's crap... Suck  my... (softly) Oh, Mom, I didn't know it was you...  eggs and milk... Okay, I won't forget.
He hangs up the phone and they start for the door again.
Let's go.
Isn't he incredible, gets along with  everybody.
Yeah, he's really got his thing  together.
Oh, eat me!
The guys all laugh and exit.
It's a quiet restaurant near a Marina. A lot of business- people in suits are eating.
CUSTOMER ONE calls for a waiter.
Waiter.
The WAITER approaches them from OUT OF FRAME.
We'd like to order now.
We see their waiter, RYKO, a blond, tanned, muscular beac bum who has definitely stayed out in the sun too long.
How you guys doin'... Could you  believe how overcast it was this  morning? Bad day for sailin', waves  are too rough and...
(annoyed) You can skip the small craft warnings.  We're in a hurry.
No prob, bud... Here's today's  dealie...
He holds up a blackboard with the day's menu.
We got... uh, veal... ah... veal... (to customer) What's this word?
Parmisan.
Yeah right. I always want to say  Paramisian when I see that. We looked  at them under the jigamabob in biology  once. Little squirmy, creepy things  that live in your intestine and...
Please... We have an appointment in  a half hour...
Wow, sounds stressful. What do you  guys do for a living?
We're lawyers.
Whoa... You got to go to school for  that or what?
(he's had enough) Look, forget the specials. We'll  take three hamburgers.
Okay, great... Any of you guys got a  pencil by any chance?
One of the customers shrugs and hands him a pen.
(impressed) All right, a Bic... How 'bout a piece  of paper?
Ryko's customers look totally disgusted as Ryko's short  attention span is interrupted by something he sees O.S.
Rick and the guys appear in the bar.
Ryko. Come on!
They all disappear into the bar area.
Be right there. (to customers) Nice rappin' with you guys.  Unfortunately I'm outta here. Someone  else will have to help you. (calling off) Skip!
The customers are pleased to get rid of Ryko. SKIP enters He's a clone of Ryko.
Like um... What's the deal, you guys  gonna order?
The customers give each other a "Here we go again" look
They're laughing uproariously and carrying on as Ryko com over and sits down.
Hi pals.
The guys acknowledge him.
Okay... We're all here. Rick, what's  the big announcement?

All right, gentlemen, I'm not gonna  sugar-coat this thing. I've known  you guys since grade school, so I'm  gonna give it to you straight from  the hip... right from the shoulder...  without beating around the bush...  Nothing fancy, just the plain, hard  facts... tell it like it is.
Man, you're losing your audience.
Okay... This is it... I'm getting  married.
What?
You're kidding.
I don't believe it.
Fuck me!
Yes, gentlemen. Saturday after next,  I lose my amateur standing and turn  pro.
Hey, man, congratulations!
Chulo gets up and gives Rick a big bear hug... The other  guys shake his hand.
Wait a minute. You been living with  Debbie! Why do you want to get  married?
Because I love her. What can I tell  you?
You sure? This means no more partying.
No more raping and pillaging, either.  You'll have to carry on without me.
Next Saturday... That's just two  more weeks to live.
Hold it... As long as you're gonna  go through with this, the least we  can do is make sure you go out in  style.
(warming to this) Yeah, man. Let's throw a bachelor  party with drugs, booze and broads.
Yeah. Right. All the things that  make life worth living.

Sounds swell... I'm really touched.  And my getting married's not gonna  change a thing between me and my  pals. We're still gonna go bowling  on Tuesdays, play cards on Fridays  and wear women's clothes on Sunday  night. I love you guys... I always  will.
Let's have a toast.
The guys all raise their glasses.
To Rick.
To us.
To girls with big pairs.
Yeah, right on, etc.
As they down their drinks, we:
We SEE a couple of very contemporary looking 15-year-olds going into a very "now" clothing store -- like Fred Segal When the door opens, loud ROCK 'N ROLL MUSIC blasts out.

Inside the store we see all the sales clerks grooving  narcissistically to the music like they're at a disco. Th cashier, PHOEBE, has devoted her life to following the cu trends and fads no matter how inane they may be. Today sh in a reggae mode, her hair wound into tight dreadlocks, a she sways lost in the ozone to the music. A CUSTOMER  approaches her with a purchase.
I'd like to pay for these.
Huh... What... Oh sure, wait till  this song is over.

She floats off again... One of the young MALE CUSTOMERS approaches an attractive  salesgirl. This is DEBBIE THOMERSON, Rick's intended. She seems to be the only sane employee in the place because s actually working, putting clothes on the racks. This  impression of sanity fits her, as she is level-headed, an has a clear sense of herself. She can also take a joke, t her engagement to Rick.
Excuse me, where can I try on these  pants?
Right over here.

She leads the Customer to the try-on booths. The Customer enters one. We SEE that the saloon-style doors of the boo have been hung too high, so as he takes off his pants, hi underwear is exposed to the world. We PULL BACK, REVEALIN other people in other booths, their bare asses clearly in sight. No one in the store seems to care, however, as the are much too busy dancing. The front door opens and BOBBIE, a very sultry and earthy looking girl with long, dark hair, pushes inside. She is  O'Neill's girl and Debbie's best friend... She's also som who would party every night if given half a chance.
(excited) Debbie... I don't believe it. I'm so  excited.
Bobbie, what are you talking about?
O'Neill just tole me. It's sooo  great... I don't believe it.
Phoebe crosses to them.
What's happening?
Debbie's marrying Rick.
...Really?
Yes, it's true.
Ohmygod.

The girls screech and jump around, hugging each other in  sheer joy. A MALE CUSTOMER, moved by this outpouring of  affection, moves over and gets in the middle of the girls enjoying every moment of being hugged by three women at o
(to Customer; realizing) Would you get out of here.
Reluctantly the guy retreats back to the Calvin Klein jea rack.
Does Cole know about this?
Really -- you went with him for two  years.
He still thinks I'm going with him.  I'm going to break the news to him  tomorrow.
He's not gonna be happy. And your  parents can't be too thrilled either.
No. As far as they're concerned the  only good Rick is a dead Rick. But I  don't care... it's my decision.
(oblivious) I'm totally blown away. You're getting  married. It seems like only yesterday  I showed you how to have oral sex.
Deb, I want to throw you a shower.
Oh, that's really sweet. I'd love  that.
We'll invite all the girls.
I don't believe it... Mrs. Rick Stahl.
The girls all start to scream and carry on all over again

Rick is cooking dinner in the cramped combination kitchen living room. He has about five dishes going at once as he dashes from stove to refrigerator. He grabs some hamburge meat, rolls it into a ball, then slaps it on the counter. then takes a steam iron and presses it on the patty. Debbie comes in the front door and crosses to him and hug him tightly, kissing him sweetly.
(between kisses) God, you're a slob.
But a fabulous cook.
What are we having?
It's either meatloaf, Swiss steak or  charred flesh. I won't know till  it's finished.
(looking at the stove) I think your dinner's burning.
Rick crosses to the stove. A small fire is coming out of of the frying pans. He douses it with water.
Don't worry... it's supposed to do  this.
(setting the table) Want to hear something great? Bobbie  and Phoebe are throwing me a shower.  It's really gonna be fun.
Not as much fun as the bachelor party  the guys are throwing for me.
You're going to have a bachelor party?
Of course. I'm a traditional guy...  It's a traditional event. (he brings all the  food to the table) Well, what do you think?
It looks awful.
Yes, but looks are deceiving... (takes a bite) Not in this case, however.
Are you going to have women at your  party?
No, sweetheart, it's a stag party.  Does stay home.
I'm not talking about does. I'm  talking about hookers.
Oh, those. Why do you ask?
Because from what I've heard, it's a  tradition and you're a traditional  guy.
Rick grabs her; starts kissing her passionately on the ne
Deb, you is my woman now. I is yo  man. No painted lady ever gonna come  between us.
I need you to promise.
Okay, you got it. I got a way we can  seal the deal -- what'd you say?
He grabs her. They kiss and slide down onto the table,  knocking the dishes to the floor.

Through the iron gates of an impressive-looking estate co Debbie in her convertible VW Rabbit. She pulls up behind new Porsche 911 and a Jeep, all decked out with rifles, n and other hunting equipment. As she walks down the path t the house, she sees something off in the distance that  startles her.
A large brown grizzly bear appears to be entering the sid door of the house.
(calling O.S.) Cole?... Cole!
The "Bear" turns around. We SEE that the bear is, in fact dead. It is being carried by a tall, handsome HUNTER. He  waves to Debbie and indicates for her to follow him insid
Debbie opens a rustic-looking door and peers in.
Cole?
Over here, Deb... in the Smokehouse.

CAMERA PANS WITH Debbie as she enters the room. She passe several trophies, guns and stuffed animal heads hanging f the wall. She makes her way past some sections of an  undetermined animal's anatomy hanging from hooks suspende from the ceiling. Finally we see COLE WHITTIER, a Steve G look-alike... rugged all-American, and heir to the Whitti Plastic Wrap fortune. Despite his jockish good looks and  outward arrogance, there's something in his manner that i definitely unsavory. As Debbie approaches him we SEE that he is butchering som unfortunate friend of the forest on the table in front of him. (NOTE: For the squeamish, all of this is done OUT OF FRAME. The only thing we should HEAR are the delightful S of TAXIDERMY.)
Hi, Deb. Just got back from the  mountains. (as he cuts in with a  surgeon's skill) Isn't this a beauty?... It's gonna  look great in the den.
Debbie tries her best not to look down at what he's doing
Cole, we've got to talk.
Finally realized Rick's a jerk, huh?
No, Cole, I...

(lifting an organ of  some sort O.S.) It's all right, I forgive you. I'm  not the vengeful type. We'll forget  what happened. Why don't we take a  trip together? Maybe kill a few lions  in Kenya over Christmas.
Cole, listen to me... I've got to  tell you...
You know, when you dumped me for  that wimp, I thought, Cole, she'll  be back. God wants the two of you to  be together, and sure enough...
Cole, I'm marrying Rick.
(confused) You're marrying him? Then why are  you coming back to me?
I'm not. I just thought I should  tell you myself before you heard it  somewhere else.
Cole stops what he is doing for a beat and just stares at Debbie intensely. Then he returns to his work with a rene enthusiasm, chopping, slashing and slicing.

You know how that makes me feel,  Deb? Wanta know how that makes me  feel? (softly) Angry, Deb. (a little louder) Yesss, that's the word, angry. But  if he makes you happy, you go right  ahead. I want you to be happy, Deb. (a little nuts) No matter what, no matter how angry  it makes me, no matter how much it  hurts. Be happy, Deb. Be oh, so very,  very happy.
Cole, I'm sorry, I...
That's all right, Deb. Go be happy  and smile a lot, Deb. Do it for me.
(uncomfortable) I'm going now, Cole.
I understand, Deb. 'Bye... be happy.
Debbie exits and we PUSH IN ON Cole. Something on his fac says, "Hi! I'm really out of my mind."

DR. STAN is Rick's older brother and a proctologist. Alth he's only in his early thirties, he thinks and acts like  someone in their early 70's. A little on the pompous side Stan is never without his pipe.
Okay, Rick, hold out your arm.
He crosses to a sterile container and takes out a syringe
You wouldn't hurt your own brother,  would you? (looking at the needle  cautiously) I changed my mind. I don't need a  blood test. The marriage is off. I --
Just then, Stan sticks the needle in his arm.
(continuing) You always were sneaky, Stan, very  sneaky.
Rick, marriage will be good for you.  It's done wonders for me.
True, you're a lot handsomer now.  Don't you have enough blood already?
(without much  conviction) You won't miss a thing about being  single... The wild parties, the  different girls every night, running  around like a maniac... God, I miss  that.
Stan, you're depressing me... Hey, I  didn't know you were going to fill  'er up. Just take a couple of gallons,  okay?
Stan removes the needle and hands Rick a cotton ball.
(continuing) That's an even trade... a cotton  ball for all my blood.
(returning to this  world) Okay, Rick, all finished. I can't  wait for that bachelor party... I  need the action.
CAMERA FOLLOWS them as they go out into the hall.
(continuing) Don't say anything to my wife about  it.
They pass an open examining room. Stan's wife, TINA, is a a doctor and is examining an old man. She's not as tiny a her name suggests. In face, she's more like over-sized.
Hi, Tina.
Rick moves to hug her and he notices that Tina has her fi up the old guy's ass.
(looking up) Rick... (to PATIENT) Mr. Goldsmith, this is my brother-in- law. He's getting married.
(without turning around) Congratulations.
Tina turns to a NURSE.
Nurse, will you take over?
The nurse shrugs and sticks her finger up the patient's r end as Tina hugs Rick.
(continuing) I'm so happy for you.
Rick hugs her, uneasily trying to make sure her right han doesn't come anywhere near his face.

Debbie and Rick and her MOM and DAD are having a frustrat game of tennis behind her parents' plush home. Mr. Thomer is a stockily-built guy in his fifties who prides himself being tough and competitive. His wife loves to shop. As f as she's concerned, appearances are everything. Neither o them likes Rick's appearance or anything else about their future son-in-law. Mr. Thomerson slams the ball to Rick;  Rick slams the ball back and drives it over the fence, ou of the court.
Oops!
(frustrated) All right, who serves?
You do, Daddy.
Mr. Thomerson serves the ball to Debbie, who hits it over the net to her mother, who hits it to Rick, who slams it  over the fence, out of the court. Mr. Thomerson does not  look pleased.
Rick, hit the ball easier, son. You  don't have to kill it.
Can't I just maim it a little?
Er... perhaps we ought to stop now.
No. Let's at least finish the set.
Rick starts humming the "ABC Wide World of Sports" theme  loudly. Mr. T. gives him a disgusted look and serves the  ball. Rick smashes the ball and sends it over the fence, of the court.

A middle-aged COUPLE are sitting on some lawn furniture t to read the newspaper. A tennis ball comes down from the and hits the guy squarely on the top of the head. PULL OU to REVEAL that they're surrounded by dozens of tennis bal
One of these days I'm gonna burn  Thomerson's court to the ground.
Rick and Mr. Thomerson are having a heart to heart chat o some lemonade in front of the tennis court.
Well, I have to admit my game's a  little rusty, but I love polo. It's  unrelenting, a constant challenge to  the senses. Really a beautiful  experience.
Rick, I want to cut through the b.s.
I'd love that.

(sitting on his anger) Good. I think you're an asshole. No,  let me correct that, an immature  asshole. Which is fine, except you're  marrying my daughter and I'm afraid  my grandchildren are going to be  little assholes.
Mr. Thomerson, I...
Let me finish. Debbie's an adult.  She can do what she wants. But if  you want your marriage to last, you're  going to have to change some things  about yourself. If I may make some  suggestions...
Feel free.
First, you're a slob. You have to  dress for success. Second, your  outlook on life...
As Mr. Thomerson drones on, Rick shifts uncomfortably in chair, focusing his attention on Debbie, her mother and h older, cynical cousin, ILENE, who are sitting nearby on t rear patio.
I'm using the same caterer for the  shower I had for our Christmas party  last year.
Great, Mom.
If I were you, I'd worry less about  the shower and more about Rick's  bachelor party.
Ilene, why would I want to do that?  I trust Rick.
Of course you do. I trusted my ex,  Mel, too. Cousin, I can only talk  from experience. What do you think  they do at these parties, have tea  and play scrabble?
Ilene, Rick promised...
Debbie, don't be naive. Men are pigs.
(trying to change the  subject) Girls, why don't we go inside for  lunch. (calling to Mr. T) Boys, would you mind bringing in  that lemonade?
In a second... (to Rick) And you're irresponsible. Show some  initiative, try to better yourself,  stop showing off, actions speak louder  than words.
Well, sir, that's quite a list. But  you're absolutely right. And if I  work hard at it, I think I can be a  totally changed person by the time  we finish lunch...

Mr. Thomerson rolls his eyes, knowing he's been wasting h breath. He grabs the pitcher of lemonade and Rick grabs t tray, which is filled with fresh lemons. They get up at t same time and collide, sending the lemonade all over Mr. and the lemons bounding over the fence.
The Neighbor we saw before is reading his paper when an  avalanche of lemons comes flying at him, joining the tenn balls on the lawn.
I hate those people... I really do.
The Thomersons, Rick, Debbie and Ilene are just finishing lunch. The DOORBELL RINGS. Mr. Thomerson gets up to answe it. Standing there is Cole, wearing his tennis shorts.
Hi, everybody. Am I late?
Not at all. We're just finishing  lunch.
Cole crosses to the table and kisses Mrs. T's hand gallan
Good to see you, Mrs. Thomerson.  Hello, Debbie.
He turns to Rick.
